722783f-c.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 122nd Street (West)
722783f-c.text:
Riverside Drive, at the S.E. corner of West 122nd Street. This
is the location of the Riverside Baptist Church, of which the tower is
mainly shown. This view northward, is as seen from in the grounds of
Barnard College (Athletic Field on Broadway, at the S.W. corner of West
119th Street). The smaller tower is atop the Administration Building
of the Union Theological Seminary, and is located directly at the N.W.
corner of Broadway at West 120th Street.
1936.
Walter L. Bogert.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
The same.
1936.
Walter L. Bogert.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
A view of the two spires, as seen westward from Broadway at West
120th Street. Partially shown on the left, is Brinckerhoff Hall, oc-
cupying the S.W. corner of Broadway at Uwst 120th Street.

722786f-a.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 122nd Street (West)
722786f-a.text:
Riverside Drive, at W. 122nd Street, showing a northerly
approach to the Riverside Baptist Church. The photographer is
viewing the construction from a ooint near 120th Street.
View 2 shows the completed edifice,as photographed in a
southward direction along dlaremont Avenue from a point above
122nd Street. The six story Dacona Hall is at the S. W. corner
there.
View 1: July 192)
View 2: May 1931
George L. Balgue
MAY BE REPRODUCED

722939f-a.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 122nd Street (West)
722939f-a.text:
RIvERSIDE PMRE.
(1)
Rivereide Drive, at Wast 122nd Street, and showing the tomb of
General U.S. Grant, with the Jersey Highlands for a background. This
view was photographed from No. 130 Claremont Ave.
March 23, 1916.
. Walter L. Bogert.
NO REP(ODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, and showing a further view north of the tomb.
March 23, 1916.
Walter L. Bogert.
NO RER(ODUCTIONS.

722931f.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 122nd Street (West)
722931f.text:
Riverside Park at W. 122nd Street and Riverside Drive. Shown
is the temporary tomb of General U. S. Grant. The permanent structure
was located about one-half block to the north and directly opposite
123rd Street. See: ''Sketch of the life of General U. S. Grant'' com-
piled by Col. John J. Garnett, with programme of the Ceremonies of
the Dedication of the Grant Monument in New York, April 27, 1897.
A. N. p. v. 156
About 1885-90
Gfficial photograph, Copyrighted, for the benefit of ''Grant
Monument Association.' Carvalho, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

722934f-a.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 122nd Street
722934f-a.text:
RIvERSIDE PARE.
Riverside Drive, west side, from but not including 122nd Street.
About 1890.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

722935f-a.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 122nd Street
722935f-a.text:
Riverside Drive, from 122nd Street, showing the Hudson River and
Grant's Tomb.
Ewing Calloway.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
Neg. ~2SS2

722785f-a.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 122nd Street (West)
722785f-a.text:
(1)
Riverside Drive, at West 122nd Street, sho ing the Riverside Baptist
Church, at the S.E. corner. General Grant's Tomb, hidden by trees, is
directly opposite, and on the west side of the Drive. This view is
southward, in which direction the church tower faces. Shown on the
right, are portions of the Union Theological Seminary.
1936.
Walter L. Bogert.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
A closer view. The 7-story building adjoining the church, is
Mc Griffert Hall, a unit of Union Theological Seminary, and is located at
the S.W. corner of West 122nd Street and Claremont Ave.
1936.
Walter L. Bogert.
NO REPPODUCTIONS.
(3)
A view similar to No. 2. Shown on the right, is the Jersey shore
line, as seen across the Hudson River.

722785f-c.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 122nd Street (West)
722785f-c.text:
(1)

722788f-a.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 122nd Street
722788f-a.text:
Riverside Drive, south from a point slightly north of West 122nd Street,
showing.on the right.the Tomb of General U.S. Grant, in which the great
Civil War hero and President of the U.S. with his wife, lie in two
stone caskets on a sunken level open to public view, and on the left;
Riverside Church (Baptist), at the S.E. corner of West 122nd Street.
Gontiguous to the latter is, the 7-story MoGiffert Hall Building, at the
S.W. corner of Claremont Ave. (extreme left). On the east side of
Claremont Ave. are seen several low units of Union TTheological Seminary.
The Hudson River and the shore of the state of New Jersey appear on the
right.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS.

722938f-c.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 122nd Street (West)
722938f-c.text:
(1)
Riverside Drive, west side, at West 122nd Street, showing the Tomb
of General U.S. Grant. The body of Grant, hero of the Civil War, to
whom General Lee of the Confederacy surrendered at Appomattox, and twice
President of the United States, and that of his wife, lie in two caskets
on a sunken level within this monument. The Tomb is open to the public
and is a major point of interest to visitors to the metropolis. This
view is southward from a point in Riverside Park and shows the northern
(left) and western (right) sides of the Mausoleum. The towered structure
in the background is the Riverside Baptist Church, at the S.E. corner of
West 122nd Street and the Drive. IIt is often called the Rockefeller
Church; it having been built by the Rockefeller family.
June 2, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, but viewed northward and showing the entrance, which is
the south side. At the extreme right appears a part of the International
House, which is on the east side of the Drive, slightly north of West
122nd Street. It is a unit of Columbia University.
June 2, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

722781f-a.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 122nd Street (West)
722781f-a.text:
Riverside Drive (running from left foreground to right background,
past the church), east side, south from and including West 122nd Street,
showing the Riverside Church (Baptist), at the S.E. corner of West 122nd
Street. Adjoining the church (left) is No. 620 West 122nd Street, at the
S.Wl corner of Claremont Ave., known as McGiffert Hall. This view was
taken from the esplanade of the Tomb of General U.S. Grant.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS.

722932f-a.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - 122nd Street (West)
722932f-a.text:
Riverside Drive, between West 122nd and 123rd Streets. Shown is the
temporary tomb of qeneral U.S. Grant, at Riverside Park, completed August 7,
1885. This photograph was taken August 9, 1885, by Mr. Howard Brown.
The original negative is now (1936) owned by Mr. Louis Brown (brother),
417 Liberty Street, Newburgh, N.Y. Mr. J.B. Niland, 1844 Arthur Ave..
N.Y. City, has a copy of the negative, from which this print was made on
October 29, 1956.  The present (1936) tomb is 112 block farther north,
directly opoosite 123rd Street. For an account' of the burial, See
''SMetch of the life of General U.S. Grant, compiled by Col. John J. Garnett,
with the Programme of the Ceremonies of the Dedication of the Grant Monument
in N.Y., April 27, 1897.'' A.N. p.v. 156.
August 9, 1885.
Mr. Howard Brown.
MAY BE REPPODUCED.
